captions.text:
Word up homies! Welcome back to
Thug Notes. This week we settin sail with
Moby-Dick by Herman Melville.

This big ass book starts when some
playa callin himself Ishmael decide he wanna
get himself a lil’ taste of life as a whaler.

But before mah boy finds a crew to
join up, he rolls over to the Spouter inn

where he hooks up wit some tatted-up harpooner
named Queequeg. Not long after, they get all
tight and start kickin it Bert and Ernie style.

So Ishmael and Queequeg fly they
colors and crew up on a hoopty-ass boat called
the Pequod.

After a while the ships top-dog
Ahab struts up to the deck with his janky

ivory leg and startin layin down some real
talk. He say the Pequod only got one mission:

to find Moby Dick- the white whale that took
his leg- and straight OJ that bitch.

After about 500 pages of Ishmael
goin off bout whaling bullsh**, the Pequod

cruises up to a ship called the Rachel, where
Ahab starts jabbering with the captain.

He axe Ahab if he wanna do em a
solid and help search for a lost boat with

his son on it. But Ahab shakes dat load off
cuz he only got one thing on his mind: dat
Mo- Deezy.

Finally they find Moby lurkin in
the water and chase his pasty ass for three

days. On the third day, Moby’s fat ass RAMS
the Pequod, which start sinkin. Now Ahab ain’t

goin out like no bitch, so he keeps it clutch
and goes toe-to-toe with moby D. He whips

out his chrome and shanks dat whale, but Moby
ain’t playin no mo’ and drags his ass
to the deep. Woo! He dead.

In the end, the whole crew go belly-
up cept my boy Ishmael, who gets saved by
the righteous cats of the Rachel.

Open up yo eyes and peep this
character foil, son. unlike Ahab’s crochety

ass, Ishmael know how to deal wit all the
bunk-ass sh** the world droppin on him. Check
it-

See, my boy Ishmael ain’t trippin
bout the fact that the world’s a twisted

place that gonna burn a brotha. In fact, he
totally cool with the fact they ain’t nothing

you can do but sit back and accept it. Whereas
Ahab don’t take sh** from nobody, even God
himself.
To Ahab, Big Moby sometimes representing God.

In the game of life, Ahab don’t wanna just
play the hand he was dealt. Naw blood. He

wanna spit in the face of the dealer, Cuz
ain’t nobody gonna impose rules on Ahab

without a fight. So be it the Sun, God, or
eternity itself, Ahab gonna step up and buck
it- even if it kills him.

So what’s Ahab’s beef with da big G really
all about? To Ahab, God runs

every part of this janky-ass world like a
tyrant that ain’t got no accountability.

What’s worse, they always gonna be some
simple-ass fools duped in to thinking that

all them injustices ain’t no thang. Only
Ahab sees that God doin em straight dirty.

And even God aint gettin away with punkin
Captain A.

But since Ahab ain’t got his glock
9 handy, he gotta strap up with a special

harpoon to merc this whale. Ahab dunks the
harpoon in the blood of three pagans, and

even BAPTIZES his new piece sayin “I do
not baptize you in the name of the father,
but in the name of the devil.
But other times, that blubbery

mess reppin all the evil in the world. And
since evil existin everywhere up in this hood,

some sailors swear they’ve peeped Moby in
multiple places at once. And other times,

Moby Dick is a symbol for an empty, Godless
universe.

Since whiteness is both the lack of
color AND the combo of all colors, that whale

is a swimming symbol of the raw truth that
no matter how you spit it, the sum total of

all the things in the universe is a big fat
nothing.

So that whale servin as a nasty
reminder that if you gonna live a life seeking

meaning, you best prep yourself for a whole
lot of pain and misery, B. And if you’ve

got the balls to face the universe’s emptiness,
you’ll see that we all like Ishmael- just

a bunch orphans floating aimlessly in a sea
that keeps flowing like it don’t even give
a sh**.

But keep floating, homies. Cuz
somewhere out there, we all got our own Rachel

that’s there to save us. See you next week,
B.

title: Moby Dick - Thug Notes Summary and Analysis

comments.author: Casey Brooks

comments.text:
I'm sad that BET doesn't give you the time slot (4 min??  I mean, 'Come 
On?!?) to do the full Thug Notes.  It's so much richer and comprehensive.  
(Nice Job!)  It is actually informative.  Ahhh.. TV.  Tirelessly stripping 
away any intellectual value of its content.  **sigh**

I find the omission (by everyone) of the whaling tasks, which take a major 
part of the story, surprising.  It struck me as just as important, and 
relevant to Ahab's tale.  It seemed to make an argument about the toil of 
man, it's bloody and cruel work, and the joy of exploitation.  But rather 
than a condemnation of that state, it's a compassionate, albeit sad, 
understanding.  His depiction of the crew as being at the mercy of the 
Captain, as well as the economy of the time - risking their very lives for 
a meager living and bathed in gore when successful - shows a measure of 
sympathy. 

Perhaps Melville is also depicting a parallel sympathy for the whales, 
embodied by Moby himself.  Moby too is a slave to whaling but represents a 
violent rebellion against it.  To be fair to Ahab, he also rebels against 
whaling, foregoing normal whale hunting at the risk of mutiny.  He has 
chosen to live outside of its system to pursue a single maniacal 
obsession.  He has literally been scarred by the violence of the career and 
has devolved into having the violence of whaling as his sole focus.  The 
loss of his leg has been the biggest event in his life and since it was 
born from violence, he can only see violence as the retributive solution to 
his state of life.  Except for Ishmael, whaling is the entirety of life for 
all the characters, all of whom are victims of its violence and 
exploitation.

I might be reading into it a bit more than what is there, or am off in my 
interpretation, but the whaling does occupy a huge part of the book and 
seems to be an important component of Melville's message.  I was quite 
surprised by it's voluminous inclusion actually, and pleasantly so.  (For 
the record I'm a vegan, so no 'You're pro-whaling!?!' baiting.  **grin**)

To be fair to Thug Notes - you only have 4.5 minutes to cover a 
symbolically rich story, so some aspects (perhaps more nebulous in their 
interpretation) need to be omitted. ﻿

That implies that calves and piggies aren't adorable. That's not the full 
reason why people think it's okay to eat them. In truth, people are blinded 
by cultural views of right and wrong. They'd say that killing and eating, 
say, a guinea pig is wrong. However, guinea pigs were traditionally eaten 
in the South American countries that the came from. (I use the example of 
guinea pigs because those are what put everything into perspective for me.)
While some whales are endangered, I don't think that when the book was 
written that they were. If they were endangered, I'm not sure how many 
people would have known anyway. So if you want to complain about whaling in 
Moby Dick, I must assume that you're also against hunting forest animals 
and have a problem with modern animal farming practices.
Sorry that this is so long. Got a bit carried away!

comments.text:
Animal consumption and cruelty is a different moral issue from conservation 
and the protection of biodiversity. Whales are more important than cows 
because there are fewer of them, and they are mega-fauna. However, any wild 
animal in that it is a part of an eco-system is more valuable than a 
domesticated animal. The initial post is hating on people who want to help 
whales and still eat industrial meat. My point is these are two separate 
issues and your opinion on the morality of consuming chicken should have 
little to do with your opinion of protecting ecosystems and their 
megafauna. The idea that the original post is based off of is BS, which is 
that all animals need to be considered equally valuable. The last mating 
pair of a species, is worth more than a whole factory farm's worth of 
chickens.

based on biodiversity. Whales are smarter than pigs and cows, and they play

comments.text:
I always thought that this book's big theme was "Obsession." I mean, 
Melville is quoted, "the definition of a classic [peice of literature] is a 
book everyone wants to say they've read, but no one wants to read." I think 
that huge chunk of bullshit in the middle is to teach the reader the true 
feeling of obsession. To emphasize the one-mindedness of Ahab and to impart 
that feeling in a way that no other book has done before it, or at least on 
purpose.

You'd have to be obsessed to actually read all of Moby Dick, and at the end 
of it, all you really get is the bragging rights to say you did.

You'd have to be obsessed to scour the globe to kill a whale, and at the 
end of it, all you really get is a dead whale.

"I would say that is dishonest"

What I meant was that it is rather dishonest that you would tell Petr Vacek 
that the transcendental isn't in the realm of proof, but rather, as I 
understood it, knowledge about it is purely theoretical. Yet the tradition 
of metaphysical thought you are employing has it's roots in european 
metaphysical thinking, which itself has it's basis in Christianity, which 
is a tradition based on revelation and inter-subjective, divine proofs. The 
form of thinking you are employing is therefore not something a prior or 
asocial, in the sense that it is represents some sort of universal, default 
human mode of thinking. It is historical and socially conditioned and 
passed down. Again, a historical evolution of something is not an argument 
against it, but it does show that it is manifestly bogus for you to claim 
that the knowledge about transcendental, as it has been understood in 
Christian thinking, is purely theoretical or a prior, since it is 
underlined by host of claimed proofs, experiences, social education and 
culture, which then guides further thinking and assumptions. It is 
therefore more contingent and posteriori.  

And in this sense I claimed that you were being dishonest, since your a 
prior, purely theoretical thinking is ultimately based on a religion, that 
is anything but purely a prior or theoretical. You are denying the 
historical contingency and cultivation of your thinking, which questions 
it's a prior status and it's supposed a prior truths. And if you extended 
your claim about the (dis)connection between proof and the transcendental 
to Christianity, you should deny that the reports and revelations of the 
bible can be used as proof of Christianity.

I would also ask you that if you move your transcendentalist thinking from 
the realm of proof, then on what can you really base it's ontological 
validity on? There are a huge number of competing metaphysical, 
transcendental traditions of thinking in human history and modern world. 
What makes your own ontologically exempt, if not only it's historical basis 
in Christianity?


"For example, Descarte's "I think therefor I am" has no basis from 
empirical observation; it can be grasped entirely independent of observable 
experience and I would consider it a tautology, even though such thought 
still transcends the thinker in many ways; that's not theoretical.

ie. I don't theorize I exist, I exist and as a result I can theorize."

I would say there are few problems with this famous claim:

1) "I" is taken here for granted, based on experience of the self. But 
whether it truly is "I" that thinks is no clear. The "I" might be an after 
effect only, as we have some reason to suspect based on our understanding 
of consciousness and sub-consciousness.

2) Is it really so that "I think, therefore I am" is so independent from 
observable experience? Think about your daily experience. Do you think "I 
think, therefore I am" constantly? I would think not. The majority of our 
day to day experience is, I would claim, really spent in a kind of 
automatic state, in which we act and even think purely without any "I" and 
without any constant self-consciousness of the "I". Yet in the seriality of 
our thoughts, at some points the idea "I am" or "I think" emerges only 
briefly. We the observe this experience in our inner state and take it to 
be the whole of conscious experience. But we don't go on in our daily lives 
constantly thinking "I am now writing on my laptop, I am now walking down 
the street, I am now thinking of me thinking" etc. In this sense, the 
question rises just how much "I think, therefore I am" is an a prior truth 
and condition.

3)While you do make valid points and I would grant that some form of 
non-theoretical basis is required for thinking, none of this infers a 
transcendental  God, it doesn't answer how you connect your transcendental 
thought to the concrete world of inter-subjective human thinking and it 
doesn't answer how you can claim that your transcendental thinking is not 
subject to proof, since it is ultimately based on tradition of proof.

comments.text:
+MRKetter81

"No, you didn't... you simply stated you found it confusing and went on a 
tirade. You want to know all these specifics on the ontological concept of 
God and then proceeded to throw a rench at everything you find difficult to 
comprehend. I don't have the time or patience to argue every erroneous 
conclusion you draw and write a giant theodicy. If you studied Leibniz then 
you understand that there are specifics to each instance to which you are 
referring and you've contextually crossed those categories in each question 
you concluded.
'unbeing' is something of the nature of evil, sin is a more specified 
instance."

I do admit that my opposition to such a notion may have motivated my 
questions, although I claim that I do not draw any conclusions. I ask 
questions which make sense to me. I suspect that I may have crossed certain 
contextual categories in doing so and thus violated the background logic of 
some philosophy seeking to address such questions, which defeats the 
purpose of asking. I however do not believe this is necessarily an error. 
If my questions violate the logic of some predetermined philosophical way 
of thinking (Leibniz, for an example, of whom I admit I only have a very 
rudimentary understanding of), that doesn't concern me. Such violations are 
necessary if one wishes to criticize such systems, rather than fight 
withing their own, irrefutable logic.

 Personally I just often find the philosophical thinking of metaphysical 
philosophers as rather socio-historically naive. They take culturally 
conditioned and changeg concepts (evil, for an example) and abstract them 
through their systems of apparent objective reason as to make them appear 
more universal and eternal than they perhaps are, while they are guided by 
a host of cultural background assumptions, which form the basis of their 
reason, not to mention, that most such philosophers had no idea of 
evolutionary development of humanity and our mind and thus assumed undue 
objectivity to their reason, But I digress. 

"No, I would simply ask you to explain the concept of 'need' at all. Such a 
claim is an abstract notion with no binding outside of an required 
ordinance; how does your worldview account for such a thing?"

I would claim that need is essential for the emergence of any motivation to 
do anything, at least as far as human psychology goes, but of course I 
cannot claim that this applies to eternal God. I would however ask you 
whether you yourself can either be certain of the fact, that it doesn't, 
this once again being a human supposition without any first hand knowledge.

"Yes it occurred to me and the same can be applied to any worldview and 
says neither about either. One worldview thinks the other one is deceived; 
which leads to an apparent paradox. Leading to the next point."

You are of course correct here. A socio-historical analysis of the origins 
and functions of certain ways of thinking of course doesn't disprove the 
ontological validity of such ways of thinking. But it does advise one to be 
careful of the seductive logic of such views and and apply comparative 
criticism to them, questioning the whole of their metaphysical basis. There 
is no reason (concrete societal conditions being excluded) that such a 
process of metaphysical rationalization could not have been or still be 
directed toward any other religious entity in history (Zeus, for an 
example) with perhaps very much the same results.

"Because you haven't crossed any boundaries between such fixed 
presuppositions. On what basis are you making any claims at all? If by the 
laws of logic or morality, then you would be bound to explain how such laws 
are universally invariable and binding to the circumstances between both 
worldviews. If you make a criticism of someone else's presuppositions, I 
think it's fair to ask on what basis your worldview can account for such 
abstract notions and how are they binding. As you stated, otherwise this 
dialogue is useless; I would concur. Unless you planned on following 
universal invariable rules that are binding then any dialogue is useless; 
as any statement made by either of us is simply relative and subjective as 
you already alluded."

I would agree that dialogue between our respective ontological views is at 
this point very much pointless, as it would require massive amounts of 
exposition and definition of background ontological assumptions, for which 
either of us really doesn't have the time. And even if we were to clarify 
and provide the to each other the invariable laws behind our respective 
ontological views, which ultimately guide our logic, deductions and use of 
language, I very much doubt we could come to any agreement of things. 
Currently we speak too much past each other and it is obvious that the lack 
of common ontological basis prevents our inter-subjective comprehension or 
the inductive elimination of possibilities. I therefore move that we end 
this exchange. I thank you for your insights and criticisms. If you still 
wish to address some of the points I have made here, you are of of course 
fee to do so.

 I would claim that need is a requisite for any action (but of course you

I asked you a question because I really don't understand what you mean and

confusion. But if you feel contend with answering with just a conceited 
slur, be my quest.

"Don't know who he is, don't follow him... not all Christians follow the 
same line of reasoning anymore than atheists do; more wasted conjecture."

Elijah Olson is the commentator under who's comment we are dialoguing. My 
comment, to which you first responded, addressed the logic of his 
statements.

reason. Deducing that He is pure beings is an ontological concept."

Really? What kind of "observations within reason" can you make about 
something like God? Also, how would you know your human reason is adequate 
to the task of understanding something "incomprehensible"? As for your 
deduction, I once again question the empirical content on such claims. Does 
it not occur to you that such "deductions" might have validity only insofar 
as they correspond to the internal logic of some ontological system (a 
theory, a religion, a philosophy), in other words, some 
semantic-axiological-discoursive system. Such systems have a history of 
social production and over time become so adorned with reason as to appear 
wholly complete and logical, whereas they really have very concrete 
evidence to support them. In a different cultural context such claims and

in producing categorical, internally coherent worldviews and theoretical 
structures, but their truthfulness is a completely another matter.

"You don't like Paradoxes? Well you live in an Uni-Verse; which is unto it 
self a paradox. Paradoxes are all around you, there is little escaping 
them."

Traditionally speaking, universe doesn't really mean paradox and I really 
don't know what it means to call universe a paradox (paradoxes often 
contradict themselves. To what extend does a universe "contradict itself"? 
Is this really even possible?)

But I am aware that we live in a world of contradictions. I just find it 
somewhat suspicious when someone apparently seeks to use them to justify 
some metaphysical system, while we are yet to even ascertain as to what 
extend the universe really is paradoxical.

"According to your presupposition perhaps, but you were attacking the 
Christian concept which goes outside your presupposition"

Of course the concept goes outside my presuppositions because it's 
supporters believe and suppose it is true, while my ontological deductions 
and assumptions are fundamentally different. I don't see how this 
invalidates my arguments. Differing presuppositions are necessary for any 
criticism. But if you do not accept those presuppositions, there is little 
point in dialogue. 

 "I could easily denounce your opinion as conjecture and imaginative 
abstractions in the same manner"

With certain terminological changes, I have no doubt, but at least I do not 
suppose that merely abstracted, conjectural, cosmological theories, based 
on a religion which itself ultimately derives it's proof from 2000 years 
old anecdotal evidence, prove something.

"How then do you apply such a relative estimate on an eternal God? The 
burden of proof is yours. Likewise the burden of proof is on you to show 
how these logical bindings are even applicable to anything, much less any 
other abstract entities."

The problem here once again is the apparent incompatibility of our 
respective ontologies. The applicability of my relative estimate is only a 
problem for you, since to you God is real "pure being", while to me he is 
not. The logic of applicability is different for both of us. To me, 
Christian God is "eternal" only in the sense that human beings have made 
him appear so through cunning use of abstracted reasoning. You claim that 
the finite views of finite beings do not compare to a infinite being, but 
what this actually means is uncertain and whether it is true, no-one can 
say and once again I find it very peculiar that Christians claim that God 
is knowable and unknowable at the same time, so is there really any kind of 
reasonable frame of reference for understanding anything about a said 
being, including our limitations in regards to a such a hypothetical being? 
And even if such a being existed in reality, I do not believe that either 
of us could come to any definite conclusions about the applicability of our 
finite views in regards to such a being. I suppose that, supposing God 
existed, my relative views would have little bearing on the views of 
eternal God. But even this is problematic, because the God's "eternity" is 
once again filtered through our finite apparatus of understanding, so we 
really don't know what it means that our views are incomparable. Likewise 
we do not know what are the conditions of God's knowledge of good and evil 
and what it means that God's eternal nature somehow gives them greater 
universal applicability (we simply suppose it does). You can of course 
retort that God's eternal nature makes his views ontologically 
self-evident, but I would claim that once again the problem lies in the 
fact that even this "certainty" is based on the suppositions of finite 
human reason. This is a problem for you, since you claim the incapability 
of human reason in understanding God, yet claim that we can, using the said 
reason, deduce his nature as "pure being" as a certainty.

As for the burden of proof, I would claim that since you are making a gross 
metaphysical claim here, which covers all the levels of ontology, knowledge 
and morality, the burden of proof is really on you.

I'm sure I would, since this "understanding" is a product of 2000 years of 
socio-historical furnishing and "logicalization" by a group of "experts", 
who took it upon themselves to be the theoretical guardians and definers of 
Christian faith and philosophy (St. Augustine and Thomas Aquinas being 
perhaps the most well known, though certainly not the only ones), refining 
it through the ages to respond to any theoretical opposition or challenges. 
In time, such systems of thought are refined to the point of being logical 
to a no fault. But they are only logical in the sense that internally, as 
systems of symbols, semantics, concepts and ideas, they are coherent within 
their own logic (while no-one actually has any proof that they are true in 
the real world outside their own theoretical consistency) Thus anyone who 
does not recognize this internal logic "lacks" understanding.  


"God doesn't "need" to be loved, human beings require such a thing. God is 
pure "being" (lacking in nothing). God created all things of His own free 
accord. God doesn't need to love human beings, human beings rather need to 
love God; the requisite is on our end."

So if God doesn't need anything (lacking in nothing), why does he do 
anything? Action implies need, a requirement to achieve something to some 
end. This is one of the illogicalities of Christian God (or any "perfect 
being theorized and imagined by human beings). The logic of why such a 
being would do anything, other than dwell in it's own perfection, confounds 
me. Obviously such beings need to do something (are in need), since they 
create anything in the first place and take interest in the activities of 
finite creatures by stipulating a set of moral or ritualistic procedures 
and laws.

What is "pure being" ? And, once again, if this "pure being" "lacks in 
nothing", then why does it do anything at all? Why does it create "unpure 
being" which needs something (how can something, that needs nothing, create 
something that requires something?)? How exactly is it separate from that 
being that is not "pure"? But of course, it is just another one of those 
empty abstractions invented by Christian philosophers to give their God an 
air of philosophical grandiosity (it is one of those things, that has been 
made "irrefutable" in regards to itself), while no-one really actually 
knows what this concept means, not even it's inventors. It is really a word 
game only. 

"Now as to why evil exists,(or rather doesn't, as it is the ontological 
opposite of existence)"

I really don't understand what this means? How is evil "the ontological 
opposite of existence"? What does this even mean? Isn't this oxymoronic, 
since according to Christina faith, evil (and sin) exist in the world and 
that there is true evil? How can you then logically claim that it is "the 
opposite of existence"? Doesn't this mean that it doesn't exist? And if 
evil and sin do not exist then neither does good? Or any need to surpass 
evil? No sin, no evil, thus no good or redemption either.

" However attributing every evil act to God on the account you somehow know 
better than He is an under-sited proclamation. The book of Job openly 
displays the folly of such an error, 

“Who is this that darkens counsel by words without knowledge?"...

“Shall a faultfinder contend with the Almighty?
    He who argues with God, let him answer it.”...

“Dress for action like a man;
    I will question you, and you make it known to me.
Will you even put me in the wrong?
    Will you condemn me that you may be in the right?

God doesn't openly give an answer to Job and neither is that a requirement 
on God's part. Job is finite and God doesn't have such limitations when it 
comes to comprehending things. The Thug gives the same analysis of Paul 
Atreides in the novel Dune- Muad'dib realizes how infinite the universe is 
and how small his comprehension is of it's entirety; even the god-emperor 
in the following novel comes to the same conclusion. Yet another problem 
arises when you dictate good and evil to God; on what accord do you make 
measurement? If you are in fact atheist good and evil are subjective to a 
secular consensus and have no real eternal binding clause; your 
accusations, in such a case, are stipulated. "

As far as I can see, you are saying that my basis for criticising the idea 
of God is null, because you claim that we he is beyond our comprehension 
and thus all my thinking lacks substance. Now, of course I do not take any 
of this as literally as you probably do. To me, the whole of Christian 
religion and morality is little more than human morality and concepts made 
"divine" in order to legitimate them (and of course, the origins of 
Christianity lie in a culture and peoples who could not understand in any 
other way than metaphysically and in superstitious fashion), which then go 
through a historical process of "rationalization" theoretical refinement 
and crystallization as to appear "divine", "absolute", "timeless" and 
"unhuman". What we are doing here is really little more than a culturally 
conditioned play with words and concepts, but let's play it then.

My response is conditioned of the claims of Christians I converse with and 
the internal logic of their claims. We are all of us ultimately dependent 
of inter-subjective communication and so is Christianity in communicating 
it's concepts. The idea of Christian God is that he loves us and wishes us 
only good. This is supposed to be his "unconditioned love". Yet by his 
omniscient actions, he chooses to create a world in which the inevitable 
course of events (which he knows) will lead to great multitude of his 
children being driven to eternal suffering because they "choose" not to 
turn to God (at least this is the typical way it is explained). God's 
goodness is claimed by the Christians because he offers us a way out of our 
sinful ways, which we have "chosen". Yet he himself is fully responsible 
for the existence of this predicament in the first place, even though he 
could have created a number of other arrangements of existence, which would 
not include sin and evil. He could have created the eternal paradise, into 
which this world is supposed to be a logical progression towards, in the 
first place and bypass any needles detours of existence, which will only 
cause suffering to the beings he claims to love. His act of love is 
self-defeating, because it is conditioned on a release from suffering and 
sin he himself is ultimately responsible for, as the absolute creator of 
everything. If you claim that here are things in existence, for which God 
is not responsible for, you are denying his absoluteness. To make such a 
claim would mean that God did not create certain things in existence, which 
would question his status as "alpha and omega", the absolute and creator of 
everything.

Also, it was claimed by Elijah Olson that God gave us free will because he 
wants us to choose him in this life. He wants us to love him on our own 
accord. Now, once again this doesn't really make any sense, because it 
presupposes need for something in a being that is supposed to be perfect. 
Yet it acts as a legitimization for many Christians for why God chose to 
create things as he did. But there is no reason really for God not creating 
heaven originally as it is and is supposed to be once we (or at least some 
of us) get there. God could have created the perfect, sinless conditions 
from the start and conditions where we would exist in perfect harmony with 
him form the first place, by our very own created natures. There is no 
reason he could not have done this, since, as you claim, he doesn't need 
anything (lack in nothing). The conditions of suffering God created by his 
first act of creation (details of which he knew completely from first to 
last, being omniscient) are thus rendered redundant, since he could have 
created a world without said conditions. To claim otherwise would be to 
claim that God could not have done so, which would deny his omnipotence.

The idea of free will doesn't really absolve God of any responsibility 
either, because he knew exactly how we would choose to use such a freedom. 
His omniscience means that he is responsible for our actions, since he 
chose to create a world, which would (as he knew it) lead to such actions.

Another problem also is that by trying to nullify my arguments by moving 
God away from the reach of human comprehension (and thus criticism), you 
are nullifying your own standpoint as well. Christians make the claim that 
God is good, based on the notion that God will is communicable to mere 
mortals. This very claim acts as the basis for the argument that God is not 
evil or at least that he actually represents "good-in-and-of-itself" (this 
claim is essential to the Christian moral worldview). Yet this claim is 
made wholly from the "imperfect" standpoint of human reason and 
understanding, which you just claimed is incapable of dictating "good and 
evil" to God. Christians often refer to God's "mysterious ways" in order to 
explain away any occasion that he acts in some "unexpected ways". Yet they 
have no problem to claim next that God is good, even though his 
"incomprehensibility" has just been established. The logic here is utterly 
arbitrary and without any human reference.  If you claim that God is good, 
you are basing this on the idea that God can be know and thus we can talk 
about him in intelligible fashion. But as soon as you move him away even 
slightly from the realm of intelligibility and comprehension, any common 
ground for making any claims about his goodness of lack of goodness 
disappears. By claiming that he is beyond the criticism of human 
understanding, he also moves  away from the realm of positive affirmation.

The funny thing also is that although you made the case for Gods 
incomprehensibility in regards to human understanding, you still made a 
number of claims regarding his nature ("pure being", his relation to 
mortals such as Job etc.). If his nature is supposed to be beyond the 
understanding and judgement of finite beings, then how is it that you can 
deduce anything about him? How can he be beyond and in the realm of our 
finite understanding at the same time, when ever it suits your needs? The 
strange, paradoxical and hypocritical thing to me is that Christians (or 
anyone using some "incomprehensible" absolute as a basis for anything 
really) seem to deduce constantly wholly finite mortal things and concepts 
from this being, whose "infinity" is then claimed, once again, from a 
finite perspective.

I would also add that God's incomprehensible nature really isn't a problem 
for me. After all, there is nothing "incomprehensible" about him, since to 
me he is just a product of human imagination and abstractions. Any attempt 
to move him away from the realm of human understanding are really nothing 
more but philosophical tricks and sleights of hand, invented conditionally, 
historically and retroactively to theoretically strengthen Christianity as 
a though system, legitimization system and worldview in human social 
relations (just as any human institution becomes self-propagating if 
allowed to prosper). However, it becomes a problem for you, since to you, 
If I am not mistaken, he is real and everything said here pertains to a 
real being. Thus your claims of incomprehensibility question your 
understanding of him and your ability to make claims about him, not mine.

be those, who will not love him as he should be loved and will, knowingly 
or unknowingly, choose sin and thus be damned to eternal damnation and 
suffering for eternity. He knows that this, by his own act of creation,

regardless of the suffering it will cause and the fact that there will be a

It bothers me greatly that the Christian mentality considers this kind of

comments.text:
+syafiqjabar It's called world building; read genre fiction if you're so 
concerned with plot. The most interesting narratives aren't about the 
events that occur within them, they're about being able to understand 
people or concepts that are completely foreign to us (in this case, 
whaling) while still being able to elicit emotional reactions from us. 
Moby-Dick accomplishes this by making us believe in what's going on. Going 
into detail about how to collect and boil whale blubber made it feel 
authentic, like I was on the ship experiencing the work involved in whaling 
myself.

Yeah, it's half whaling encyclopedia and half novel, but that's what makes 
it interesting. It's an unclassifiable book.
comments.author: Jonmad17

comments.text:
I don't think you understand. That's not scientific, again that's 
convention. In terms of physics, as I stated above, white light is the 
ensemble average of all wavelengths of light at equal parts. While we can 
only see and are really only concerned with visible light (~400-700nm), 
this also includes UV, IR, X-ray, etc. Black is the absence of the same. 
This is a fundamental definition, so there is no "other system."
comments.author: Whiskey Richard

comments.text:
+Whiskey Richard Well, that depends on the color-system you are unsing ;) 
If you are speaking in terms of usual light (and also computer monitors 
etc, RGB) you are right, the more colors you punch togehter, the more white 
will the result become. 
But if you are using CMYK like in printing, exactly the opposite will 
happen: The more colors you print together, the darker and blacker it gets.

only waste one's time and take one's life.

If Ahab's beef is with God as represented by Moby Dick, then that means we 
basically have a man who devotes himself to fighting against God. But he 
ends up dying precisely because trying to fight against the powers that be 
out of rage only ends in suffering. Even though Ahab killed the whale, he 
died doing it, and was no closer to actually killing God than he was at the 
beginning. His rage blinded him to the truth, and caused him to fight 
against the world impotently.﻿
